item.title: Designing Data-Intensive Applications – Multi-Object Transactions
item.description: It's time we learn about multi-object transactions as we continue our journey into Designing Data-Intensive Applications, while Allen didn't specifically have that thought, Joe took a marketing class, and Michael promised he wouldn't cry.

item.title: Running 1000 tests in 1s
item.description: Most code doesn't require the amount of test isolation modern test runners apply by default. If you only opt into the amount of isolations you need, you can easily run 1000 tests in 1s.

item.title: Docusaurus blogs: adding breadcrumb Structured Data | johnnyreilly
item.description: Docusaurus blogs can add breadcrumb Structured Data to their blog posts. This post shows how to add it using the JSON-LD format.

item.title: Marketing Yourself As A Junior Engineer
item.description: If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles. If you know yourself but not the enemy, for every victory gained you will also suffer a defeat. If you know neither the enemy nor yourself, you will succumb in every battle.

item.title: Thomas Steinacher | The sad state of eSIM
Bare-bones Diffusion Models
item.description: To understand how diffusion models generate images, I wrote code for training a bare-bones diffusion model without all the fanciness (no “epsilon parameterization”, no “Gaussian conditionals”, no sqrt_one_minus_alphas_cumprod).

item.title: Mounting a Magic Trackpad on a Kinesis Advantage Keyboard | Pete Keen
item.description: The Kinesis Advantage is a funky keyboard with a blank spot exactly right for mounting a Magic Trackpad. But how to get it to stick there?

item.title: C# Language Mind map
item.description: This blog post contains a mind map of language features starting from C# 1 up til now - including some of the new C# 12 features that will be released in November 2023.

item.title: ChatGPT Passes Google Coding Interview for Level 3 Engineer With $183K Salary
item.description: 'Amazingly, ChatGPT gets hired at L3 when interviewed for a coding position,' reads a Google document, but ChatGPT itself says it can't replicate human creativity and problem-solving skills.
